TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I teach my child biblical principles and truths.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Read a short Bible passage or story together each day. Ask one question about God’s character or a biblical principle (e.g., “What does this tell us about God’s love?”).

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I encourage my child to have personal prayer time and Bible reading.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Help your child set a “quiet time” of 10–15 minutes each day. Provide a simple children’s devotional or Bible reading plan, and encourage discussion or journaling of insights. For younger children, read the Bible together and discuss its truths.

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I engage my child to talk about how faith applies to everyday situations in our lives.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: During meals or car rides, ask open-ended questions such as, “How do you think we can show God’s love at school/work today?” or “What would Jesus do in this situation?”

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I make church involvement a priority for my family.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Each week, discuss upcoming church events or service opportunities. Ask your child which activity they’d like to join (e.g., volunteering, small group, children’s ministry).

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I answer my child’s spiritual questions with patience and biblical guidance.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: When a question arises, stop and say, “That’s a great question!” Then explore a relevant Bible verse or use a kid-friendly resource together.

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I teach my child that obedience to God brings blessing.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Share a real-life example of how obeying God led to a good outcome. Emphasize that blessing can include peace, joy, and stronger relationships.

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I talk to my child about the importance of framing priorities and pursuits from an eternal perspective – living for heaven rather than making choices that are short-sighted.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Connect practical decisions (like spending money or time) to honoring God in the long term.

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I prioritize my child’s spiritual growth over worldly achievements.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Celebrate spiritual milestones (e.g., acts of kindness, prayer habits) with as much enthusiasm as academic or sports achievements.

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I pray with and for my child daily.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Establish a regular prayer time (e.g., at breakfast or bedtime) where you pray aloud together. Encourage your child to share personal requests and model praying for them by name. Use the acronym C.A.S.T. – Confession, Adoration, Supplication, Thanksgiving – as a guide.

TRUTH-SEEKING.statement: I teach my child that they are not to copy worldly values, but to act like a citizen of Heaven.
TRUTH-SEEKING.action: Identify cultural messages (from TV, social media, music, literature) and discuss how they compare or contrast with biblical truth (e.g., Philippians 4:8; Romans 12:2).

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model kindness, generosity, and respect towards others, living out the golden rule of relationships – “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.”
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Involve your child in a small daily act of kindness (e.g., writing a note of encouragement or giving a treat to a neighbor).

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model humility and the commitment to improve by admitting my mistakes and asking for forgiveness.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: When you lose your temper or err, pause and say, “I was wrong. Will you forgive me?”

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model good habits and discipline in the areas of eating, sleeping, exercise, and digital use.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Set aside at least one “no-phone” hour to exercise together, prepare a healthy meal, or wind down for bedtime.

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model the right order of priorities.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Verbally explain why you choose family or faith-related tasks over less important ones (e.g., “I’m turning off the TV so we can read together because family time matters.”)

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model a grateful and joyful attitude, as well as trusting in God, even when faced with challenges and stress.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Share one thing you’re thankful for each day, even on stressful days.

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model stewardship of resources by being mindful of my spending and practicing frugality.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Before making a purchase, explain your decision process and demonstrate comparing prices or saving money.

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model speaking positively about people, avoiding gossip and negative talk.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Intentionally include positive comments when discussing others; if negativity arises, reframe with kindness.

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model perseverance and grit when I approach tasks and responsibilities.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Let your child see you persist in a challenging task and verbalize, “I feel like giving up, but I’ll keep trying.”

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I demonstrate a strong work ethic and persistence in tasks.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Engage in challenging activities as a family through physical challenges or meaningful projects.

EXEMPLIFYING.statement: I model faithfulness and integrity, even when no one is watching.
EXEMPLIFYING.action: Share a personal example of doing the right thing when no one is watching.

COMMUNICATING.statement: I listen to my child without interrupting or dismissing their concerns.
COMMUNICATING.action: Practice a “two-minute rule” allowing your child uninterrupted speaking time.

COMMUNICATING.statement: I acknowledge and validate my child’s feelings, even when I disagree.
COMMUNICATING.action: Use phrases like “I see you’re upset” or “I understand this is hard for you” before offering guidance.

COMMUNICATING.statement: I make eye contact and give full attention when my child is speaking.
COMMUNICATING.action: Put your phone away or turn off the TV to focus on your child.

COMMUNICATING.statement: I assure my child that they can open up to me about anything.
COMMUNICATING.action: Provide a daily affirming statement such as, “I’m always here to listen—no topic is off-limits.”

COMMUNICATING.statement: I ask open-ended questions to help my child articulate their thoughts.
COMMUNICATING.action: Instead of yes/no questions, ask “What was the best part of your day, and why?”

COMMUNICATING.statement: I avoid using an angry tone or manner when responding to my child’s feelings.
COMMUNICATING.action: Take a deep breath or count to five before responding if emotions run high.

COMMUNICATING.statement: I make time daily to ask my child about their thoughts and experiences.
COMMUNICATING.action: At a set time (e.g., bedtime or dinner), ask, “What was one new thing you learned today?”

COMMUNICATING.statement: I guide my child toward constructive ways to handle conflicts and emotions.
COMMUNICATING.action: When upset, calmly coach them by saying, “Let’s take a moment to breathe and think of a better way to respond.”

COMMUNICATING.statement: I am open about my own weaknesses and struggles.
COMMUNICATING.action: Briefly share a personal challenge (e.g., work stress) and how you coped.

COMMUNICATING.statement: I express empathy by trying to understand situations from my child’s perspective.
COMMUNICATING.action: Reflect by saying, “So you’re feeling hurt because your friend didn’t include you. That must be very disappointing.”

ENGAGING.statement: I make it a point to be present during meal times, especially dinner.
ENGAGING.action: Turn off electronics and invite each family member to share a highlight of their day.

ENGAGING.statement: I participate in my child’s interests and activities regularly by “getting into their world.”
ENGAGING.action: Spend at least 15 minutes doing something your child loves (e.g., drawing, playing a game).

ENGAGING.statement: I attend my child’s events and special occasions whenever possible.
ENGAGING.action: Mark upcoming events on a shared calendar and discuss them in advance.

ENGAGING.statement: I put away electronic devices and focus fully during family interactions.
ENGAGING.action: Designate a “phone basket” or charging station to minimize distractions.

ENGAGING.statement: I initiate conversations with my child about their day and experiences to know them more.
ENGAGING.action: Ask specific questions like, “What was the funniest thing that happened today?”

ENGAGING.statement: I plan family activities, vacations, or traditions to build memories.
ENGAGING.action: Each week, plan a small family activity (e.g., board game night, nature walk).

ENGAGING.statement: I make time to play, laugh, and enjoy fun moments with my child.
ENGAGING.action: Schedule a 10-minute “goof-off” break (e.g., telling jokes or dancing).

ENGAGING.statement: I adjust my schedule to ensure I spend quality time with my child regularly.
ENGAGING.action: Block out a recurring “child date” in your calendar as non-negotiable.

ENGAGING.statement: I prioritize family time over work and other external commitments.
ENGAGING.action: If a work task can wait, choose to engage in a family activity first.

ENGAGING.statement: I use spontaneous moments to connect with my child.
ENGAGING.action: Seize random opportunities (e.g., during a drive) to ask a fun question or sing together.

AFFIRMING.statement: I praise my child’s efforts rather than just their accomplishments.
AFFIRMING.action: Say, “I’m proud of how hard you worked,” focusing on the process.

AFFIRMING.statement: I use words of encouragement to affirm and appreciate my child daily.
AFFIRMING.action: Write a quick note or send a text saying, “I love how you always try your best.”

AFFIRMING.statement: I avoid negative labels and judgmental statements that tear down my child.
AFFIRMING.action: Replace any negative labels immediately with affirming words.

AFFIRMING.statement: I recognize and celebrate my child’s unique strengths and gifts.
AFFIRMING.action: Point out one specific strength each day (e.g., creativity, empathy, humor).

AFFIRMING.statement: I avoid comparing my child to others and instead affirm their individuality.
AFFIRMING.action: When discussing peers, highlight what makes your child unique.

AFFIRMING.statement: I correct my child’s mistakes in a way that builds confidence rather than discourages.
AFFIRMING.action: Use a “praise sandwich” – affirm, gently correct, then reaffirm.

AFFIRMING.statement: I express appreciation for my child’s strengths privately and publicly.
AFFIRMING.action: Praise them in front of family or friends when appropriate.

AFFIRMING.statement: I intentionally speak positive and life-giving words over my child.
AFFIRMING.action: End each day with a blessing like, “I believe in you. God has great plans for you.”

AFFIRMING.statement: I reassure my child that they are loved, regardless of their performance.
AFFIRMING.action: Remind them that their value is not based on test scores or outcomes.

AFFIRMING.statement: I provide constructive feedback with kindness and encouragement.
AFFIRMING.action: After a mistake, say, “I know you can do better next time. Let’s work on it together.”

AFFIRMING.statement: I avoid shouting and losing my temper when correcting my child.
AFFIRMING.action: If you feel anger rising, pause, take a deep breath, and speak calmly.

LOVING.statement: I express my love for my child verbally every day.
LOVING.action: Simply say “I love you” at least once a day while making eye contact.

LOVING.statement: I show physical affection (hugs, pats on the back, etc.) consistently.
LOVING.action: Offer a hug in the morning, after school, or before bedtime.

LOVING.statement: I reassure my child that my love is not based on their behavior or achievements.
LOVING.action: After discipline, remind them, “I love you no matter what.”

LOVING.statement: I respond with patience and understanding when my child makes mistakes.
LOVING.action: Listen calmly first, then say, “Everyone makes mistakes; let’s work on improving together.”

LOVING.statement: I create an emotionally safe space where my child feels the security of belonging.
LOVING.action: Ask, “How can I support you today?” or “Is there anything you want to talk about?”

LOVING.statement: I avoid using love as a reward or withholding affection as punishment.
LOVING.action: Even if upset, always offer a hug or kind words.

LOVING.statement: I don’t show favoritism in the family; I show equal favor to each child.
LOVING.action: Dedicate individual time to celebrate each child’s unique strengths.

LOVING.statement: I let my child know I don’t just love them, I like them, and I enjoy their company.
LOVING.action: Identify your child’s primary love language and express love accordingly (e.g., quality time, words, acts of service).

LOVING.statement: I demonstrate my love by “speaking” my child’s love language – gifts, words of affirmation, service, time, or affection.
LOVING.action: During prayer or devotions, remind them that God’s love is unconditional and eternal.

LOVING.statement: I point my child to the source of perfect love, who is God himself.
LOVING.action: Share a personal story of how God’s love has impacted your life.

TEACHING.statement: I assign age-appropriate tasks and responsibilities to my child to help them develop independence.
TEACHING.action: Give a small chore each morning (e.g., making the bed, feeding a pet) with minimal assistance.

TEACHING.statement: I teach my child the principles of wise money management, including saving, spending, and giving.
TEACHING.action: Provide a small allowance and help them divide it into jars: Save, Spend, and Give.

TEACHING.statement: I encourage my child to think critically, solve problems, and make responsible choices instead of always providing direct answers.
TEACHING.action: When your child asks a question, respond with, “What do you think might work? Let’s try it.”

TEACHING.statement: I involve my child in basic household chores and give them tasks to build their sense of responsibility – to be a contributor rather than a mere consumer.
TEACHING.action: Dedicate 10–15 minutes daily to a “family chore time” where your child can participate.

TEACHING.statement: I teach my child the importance of healthy eating, hygiene, and personal well-being.
TEACHING.action: Let your child help plan a healthy meal or pack a balanced lunch.

TEACHING.statement: I help my child develop time management and organizational skills for school, home, and other responsibilities.
TEACHING.action: Use a checklist or calendar so your child can mark off completed tasks.

TEACHING.statement: I foster a habit of curiosity by encouraging my child to ask questions, analyze information, and seek truth through a biblical lens.
TEACHING.action: Encourage one “big question of the day” and research the answer together using Scripture and reliable sources.

TEACHING.statement: I equip my child with the skills to handle conflicts biblically and make ethical decisions in challenging situations.
TEACHING.action: Role-play a hypothetical conflict (e.g., sibling dispute) and guide them toward respectful resolutions.

TEACHING.statement: I teach my child to engage respectfully and empathetically with people from different backgrounds, beliefs, and cultures.
TEACHING.action: Share a short story or news piece about a different culture and ask, “How can we show love and respect?”

TEACHING.statement: I reinforce a love for continuous learning, self-improvement, and spiritual growth.
TEACHING.action: Model learning something new each day (e.g., a Bible verse, fun fact, or skill) and invite your child to join.

TRAINING.statement: I set clear and consistent rules and expectations for behavior.
TRAINING.action: Each morning, restate one key rule (e.g., “We speak respectfully in this house.”).

TRAINING.statement: I follow through with fair and appropriate consequences when rules are broken.
TRAINING.action: Calmly apply the agreed-upon consequence when a rule is broken.

TRAINING.statement: I remain calm and composed when disciplining my child, and avoid outbursts of anger.
TRAINING.action: If you feel anger rising, step away for 30 seconds, take a deep breath, then return to address the issue calmly.

TRAINING.statement: I explain the reasons behind rules and consequences to my child.
TRAINING.action: Briefly state, “This rule exists because…” or “This consequence is to help you learn.”

TRAINING.statement: I enforce discipline with a focus on teaching and training rather than punishment as an end in itself.
TRAINING.action: After discipline, have a short conversation: “What can we learn from this? How can we do better next time?”

TRAINING.statement: I praise and reward my child’s good behavior regularly.
TRAINING.action: Notice and praise your child when they do something right each day.

TRAINING.statement: I emphasize one-command obedience and respect.
TRAINING.action: Give a simple instruction and praise prompt compliance.

TRAINING.statement: I encourage my child to take responsibility for their actions, to apologize, and to make restitution when they are wrong.
TRAINING.action: If your child hurts someone, guide them to apologize and ask, “What can you do to make it right?”

TRAINING.statement: I adapt age-appropriate discipline strategies based on my child’s needs and life-stage.
TRAINING.action: Regularly evaluate if your approach is effective and adjust as needed.

TRAINING.statement: I balance discipline with grace and loving guidance.
TRAINING.action: End each discipline moment with a reassuring hug or kind statement like, “I love you, and we’ll work on this together.”

PEACEMAKING.statement: I demonstrate humility by apologizing when I make mistakes.
PEACEMAKING.action: Immediately say, “I’m sorry. I shouldn’t have done that,” when you err.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I regularly ask how I can improve.
PEACEMAKING.action: Once a day, ask your child, “Is there something I could do better?”

PEACEMAKING.statement: I avoid bringing up past mistakes against my child in present conflicts, instead, I identity and address the main issue.
PEACEMAKING.action: Focus solely on the present issue.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I encourage my child to resolve disagreements peacefully and respectfully.
PEACEMAKING.action: Role-play conflict resolution using phrases like “I feel…” or “I need…” when upset.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I do not let “the sun go down on my anger,” but seek to resolve conflicts as soon as possible.
PEACEMAKING.action: End the day by addressing any unresolved tension gently.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I actively listen to both sides of a conflict before making judgments.
PEACEMAKING.action: When siblings argue, ask each, “What happened from your perspective?”

PEACEMAKING.statement: I do not use words like “always” or “never” or make sweeping generalizations that are inaccurate and judgmental.
PEACEMAKING.action: Rephrase any sweeping statements with specifics.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I pray with my child about handling conflicts in a Christlike manner.
PEACEMAKING.action: When conflict arises, pause and pray together for patience and forgiveness.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I prioritize relationship-building over being “right” in family discussions.
PEACEMAKING.action: Consider, “Will this response build our relationship or tear it down?” before speaking.

PEACEMAKING.statement: I help my child understand that mistakes are learning opportunities rather than failures.
PEACEMAKING.action: When a mistake occurs, ask, “What did we learn? How can we do better next time?”

ENTRUSTING.statement: I actively seek God’s guidance in my parenting decisions.
ENTRUSTING.action: Begin each day with a prayer: “Lord, guide me in how I parent today.”

ENTRUSTING.statement: I pray daily for my child’s spiritual growth and well-being.
ENTRUSTING.action: During your devotional time, lift up your child’s name and specific needs before God.

ENTRUSTING.statement: I surrender my fears and anxieties about my child’s future to God.
ENTRUSTING.action: When anxious, write down your worries, pray over them, and visualize handing them over to God.

ENTRUSTING.statement: I encourage my child to seek God’s will in their own decisions, to focus on pleasing God.
ENTRUSTING.action: Ask your child, “Have you prayed about it? What do you think God might want?”

ENTRUSTING.statement: I prioritize my personal spiritual growth as a parent.
ENTRUSTING.action: Spend 10–15 minutes daily in Bible reading, worship, or a devotional.

ENTRUSTING.statement: I create opportunities for my child to experience God’s presence in daily life.
ENTRUSTING.action: Play worship music, hold short family devotions, or point out “God moments” in everyday situations.

ENTRUSTING.statement: I don’t over-function for my child and make them dependent on me rather than dependent on God.
ENTRUSTING.action: Encourage your child to attempt tasks independently and to pray for guidance.

ENTRUSTING.statement: I help my child develop habits of prayer, worship, and Bible study.
ENTRUSTING.action: Hold a short “family devotion” at least once a week where everyone reads, memorizes, and discusses a Bible verse.

ENTRUSTING.statement: I rest in the reality that God is in control and in charge of my child’s journey.
ENTRUSTING.action: When worrying, whisper a simple prayer: “Lord, they are Yours. I trust You.”

ENTRUSTING.statement: I trust that God has the best plans for my children, even when I don’t always understand the present.
ENTRUSTING.action: Share a personal story of how God worked unexpectedly in your life.
